newsitem.title: FRANCE: Moulinex may reduce proposed layoffs-paper.
newsitem.headline: Moulinex may reduce proposed layoffs-paper.

text.p: Appliance manufacturer Moulinex may sharply reduce the number of layoffs proposed in a recent restructuring plan by adopting shorter work hours, the newspaper Liberation said on Tuesday.
It said Moulinex's new plan, due to be presented to the staff council on October 18, may reduce the proposed elimination of 2,100 jobs in France by between 750 and 1,050.
The plan is possible due to a French law enacted in the summer that allows for a reduction in corporate charges for companies which hire more workers or reduce work hours to save jobs.

The plan by the company, which has been under pressure to tone down a radical restructuring plan to make it more competitive globally, would reduce work hours by 15 percent, cutting the workweek to 33 hours by 1998 and 31 hours in 1999.
It would also allow for flexibility during peak production periods, notably in late summer, when the workweek could increase to as much as 44 hours.
Salaries would be held at 98.3 percent of current levels, the newspaper said.
